Explanation:

  • • Potency refers to the amount of a drug needed to produce a given effect, while efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce. On a dose-response curve (typically with dose on the x-axis and response on the y-axis), a more potent drug reaches the same effect at a lower dose, meaning it is shifted to the left. Equal efficacy means the drugs reach the same maximum response (plateau) on the y-axis.
  • • From the image:
  • • Drug A's curve lies to the left of Drug B, meaning Drug A is more potent (requires a lower dose to achieve the same effect).
  • • Both Drug A and Drug B reach the same maximal response, indicating they are equally efficacious. Thus, Option D is correct.

Drug B is less potent but equally efficacious as drug D – Incorrect: If Drug D has a higher maximal response than Drug B, it is more efficacious, not equally efficacious. Also, potency comparison must show relative positions on the x-axis, which this option misrepresents.
  • • B. Drug C is less potent and more efficacious than drug A – Incorrect: If Drug C has a lower maximal response than Drug A, it is less efficacious, not more. Additionally, if it is shifted to the right of Drug A, it is less potent, but the efficacy part of the statement is incorrect.
  • • C. Drug D is more potent and more efficacious than drug B – Incorrect: If Drug D is not significantly to the left of Drug B, it may not be more potent. And if its maximal response is not higher, it's also not more efficacious. The statement may be partially true but is not fully correct based on the image.

questions.text: True about non-competitive inhibition is?
questions.correct_answer: A. Km remains same, Vmax decreases
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site (not the active site) on the enzyme, and not affected by the concentration of substrate. This changes the enzyme's structure, rendering it inactive even if the substrate is bound.
  • • Km (Michaelis constant) reflects the enzyme’s affinity for the substrate. In non-competitive inhibition, Km remains unchanged because the substrate can still bind to the enzyme.
  • • Vmax (maximum velocity) decreases, because the total number of active enzyme molecules is reduced due to inhibitor binding.
  • • Thus, the correct statement is: Km remains the same, Vmax decreases → Option A
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Km increases, Vmax remains same – Incorrect: This describes competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site.
  • • C. Km decreases, Vmax increases – Incorrect: This doesn’t describe any known classical enzyme inhibition pattern and is physiologically implausible in standard inhibition kinetics.
  • • D. Km increases, Vmax increases – Incorrect: Both Km and Vmax increasing is not characteristic of any known enzyme inhibition mechanism.

questions.text: A drug launched in market is in phase of marketting survillence is found to be associated with side effects. Which of the following parameter will tell us about drug safety
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To assess drug safety, a commonly used measure is the Therapeutic Index (TI), which is defined as:
  • • Therapeutic Index (TI) = LD50 / ED50
  • • LD50 = Lethal Dose in 50% of the population (a measure of toxicity)
  • • ED50 = Effective Dose in 50% of the population (a measure of therapeutic effect)
  • • A higher TI indicates a wider margin of safety, meaning the drug's effective dose is much lower than the dose that could be lethal. This is especially important in Phase IV (post-marketing surveillance) when rare or long-term side effects may emerge in the general population.
  • • So, LD50 / ED50 helps evaluate how safe a drug is by comparing its toxic dose to its effective dose. Hence, Option A is correct.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. ED50 / LD50 – Incorrect: This is the inverse of the therapeutic index. While it technically reflects a relationship between effectiveness and toxicity, it is not standard and lower values would misleadingly appear safer, which is confusing and incorrect.
  • • C. LD90 / ED10 – Incorrect: This is not a standard measure in pharmacology. While it might offer insight into extreme doses, it does not represent average population safety like LD50/ED50 does.
  • • D. ED90 / LD10 – Incorrect: Like option C, this is a non-standard ratio. It does not provide a reliable or meaningful measure of safety across a population.

questions.text: What is the advantage of fixed dose combination of drugs?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fixed Dose Combinations (FDCs) are pharmaceutical products that contain two or more active drugs combined in a single dosage form (e.g., a single tablet or capsule). FDCs are widely used in the treatment of conditions like hypertension, diabetes, tuberculosis, HIV, and malaria.
  • • FDCs offer multiple advantages, which include:
  • • Improved patient compliance Most significant benefit. Taking one pill instead of multiple simplifies treatment regimens, especially for chronic conditions.
  • • Reduced pill burden increases the likelihood that patients will adhere to therapy, improving outcomes.
  • • Increased efficacy Combining drugs with different mechanisms of action can produce synergistic effects, meaning better control of the disease.
  • • For example, combining two antihypertensives (e.g., an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic) provides better blood pressure control.
  • • Decreased adverse effects By combining drugs, lower doses of individual drugs may be used, which can reduce dose-related side effects.
  • • Also, some combinations may counteract each other's side effects (e.g., lopinavir + ritonavir in HIV treatment, where ritonavir boosts lopinavir levels).
  • • Why the other options alone are incomplete: A. Increases efficacy – True, but not the only benefit.
  • • B. Decreases adverse effects – True in many cases, but also not the only advantage.
  • • C. Patient compliance is improved – Perhaps the most important, but again, not the sole advantage.

questions.text: Which of the following drug causes the effects on blood pressure and HR as shown in the figure
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Let's analyze the effects of each option:
  • • A. Epinephrine (Adrenaline): Epinephrine stimulates both alpha (α) and beta (β) adrenergic receptors. It causes vasoconstriction (α1) leading to increased systolic and mean blood pressure, but it also strongly stimulates β1 receptors in the heart, leading to increased heart rate and cardiac contractility. While it increases pulse pressure, the reflex bradycardia seen in the figure is less typical as its direct β1 effects would counteract it, or the reflex would be masked.
  • • B. Norepinephrine (Nor-epinephrine): Norepinephrine primarily stimulates α1 receptors (causing potent vasoconstriction) and β1 receptors (in the heart). The strong α1-mediated vasoconstriction leads to a marked increase in systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure. This significant rise in blood pressure then triggers a strong baroreceptor reflex. The baroreceptors sense the increased pressure and respond by increasing parasympathetic (vagal) tone to the heart, leading to reflex bradycardia (a decrease in heart rate) despite the direct β1 stimulation of the heart. This perfectly matches the figure.
  • • C. Isoprenaline (Isoproterenol): Isoprenaline is a non-selective beta agonist, strongly stimulating β1 and β2 receptors. It causes vasodilation (β2), leading to a decrease in diastolic blood pressure and often a slight decrease in mean arterial pressure. It strongly increases heart rate and cardiac contractility (β1). This is the opposite of what is shown in the figure for blood pressure and heart rate.
  • • D. Dopamine: Dopamine's effects are dose-dependent. At low doses, it stimulates D1 receptors causing renal and mesenteric vasodilation. At moderate doses, it stimulates β1 receptors, increasing heart rate and contractility. At high doses, it stimulates α1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction. While it can increase blood pressure at high doses, it usually increases heart rate directly or reflexively, and the combined pattern shown (marked increase in all pressures with reflex bradycardia) is not its primary or most characteristic effect compared to norepinephrine.

This results in an exaggerated vasodilatory response, causing a drastic drop in blood pressure.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure – Incorrect:
  • • This refers to tolerance, which is a different phenomenon, where repeated administration of ephedrine can lead to reduced efficacy over time. However, this is not related to Dale's vasomotor reversal.
  • • B. High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate – Incorrect:
  • • Atropine blocks the parasympathetic effects, leading to increased heart rate and blood pressure. However, this is not a demonstration of vasomotor reversal as seen with adrenergic agonists and antagonists. Acetylcholine's effect would be blocked by atropine, not reversed.
  • • C. Increase in pulse pressure is produced by intravenous administration of isoprenaline – Incorrect:
  • • Isoprenaline (isoproterenol) is a β-adrenergic agonist, which generally causes vasodilation (due to β? receptor activation) and increased heart rate (due to β? receptor activation). This results in increased cardiac output, but it doesn't demonstrate Dale's vasomotor reversal, which involves adrenergic receptor antagonism and agonism leading to opposing effects.

questions.text: A female of 28 years of age comes to OPD with complaints of dropping of eyelid in evening time., This patient is almost symptom free in morning and muscle weakness increases during evening time. As a physician you have noticed that patient symptoms improve after neostigmine. What is your most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder caused by the production of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This results in muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. In MG, the weakness typically affects the ocular muscles first, leading to ptosis and diplopia (double vision). Symptoms tend to improve after the administration of neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • • The diurnal variation in symptoms (better in the morning and worse in the evening) is another hallmark feature of Myasthenia gravis, as the neuromuscular junction becomes fatigued over the course of the day.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome – Incorrect:
  • • Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is another disorder involving the neuromuscular junction, but it has distinct features. It is caused by autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. LEMS usually presents with proximal muscle weakness (e.g., difficulty standing up from a seated position) and impaired deep tendon reflexes. Unlike MG, LEMS symptoms improve with activity, not worsen. The hallmark of LEMS is the improvement of weakness with exercise, not fatigue during the day.
  • • C. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy – Incorrect:
  • • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, usually beginning in childhood. It affects large muscle groups, not just the ocular muscles. DMD does not improve with neostigmine, and the symptoms are generally constant, not diurnally variable like in MG.
  • • D. Dermatomyositis – Incorrect:
  • • Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness (often proximal) and skin rashes (such as a heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules). While it can cause muscle weakness, it does not typically present with diurnal variation in symptoms, nor does it improve with neostigmine.

questions.text: Drug used to differentiate between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis is?

  • • In patients with myasthenia gravis, the administration of edrophonium typically results in rapid improvement of symptoms (such as ptosis and weakness), as it increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.
  • • In cholinergic crisis, which is caused by overdose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (like pyridostigmine), the administration of edrophonium can worsen symptoms, as it further increases acetylcholine levels, leading to excessive cholinergic activity (muscle weakness, respiratory depression, etc.).
  • • Thus, edrophonium can be used as a diagnostic tool to distinguish between the two conditions: improvement of symptoms indicates myasthenia gravis, while worsening of symptoms suggests a cholinergic crisis.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Pyridostigmine – Incorrect:
  • • Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, but it does not serve as a diagnostic tool for distinguishing between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis. In fact, overdose of pyridostigmine can lead to a cholinergic crisis.
  • • C. Methacholine – Incorrect:
  • • Methacholine is a muscarinic receptor agonist used primarily in bronchial challenge tests to diagnose asthma or airway hyperreactivity. It is not used in the diagnosis or differentiation of myasthenia gravis or cholinergic crisis.
  • • D. Clonidine – Incorrect:
  • • Clonidine is an α?-adrenergic agonist used primarily in the treatment of hypertension and opioid withdrawal. It has no role in differentiating between myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis.

  • • Norepinephrine primarily acts as a vasoconstrictor (alpha-1 agonist) to raise blood pressure, but it does not have the bronchodilatory effects required to manage the breathing difficulty associated with anaphylaxis. Therefore, adrenaline is preferred over norepinephrine in this scenario.
  • • C. Dopamine – Incorrect:
  • • Dopamine can be used to increase blood pressure in cases of shock, but it does not address the bronchoconstriction and other symptoms of anaphylaxis. It is not the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis, where adrenaline is preferred due to its broader therapeutic effects.
  • • D. Isoprenaline – Incorrect:
  • • Isoprenaline is a beta-agonist that primarily causes bronchodilation and increased heart rate. While it may help with breathing difficulty, it does not provide vasoconstriction and may not be effective for hypotension in anaphylaxis. Adrenaline, which has both alpha and beta effects, is much more effective in treating anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the action of dopamine at low doses?
questions.correct_answer: A. It increase renal blood flow
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The increase in renal blood flow is one of the primary effects of dopamine at low doses, which is why it is used in certain clinical settings to support renal function.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. It produces positive chronotropic action – Incorrect:
  • • Dopamine at low doses does not significantly affect heart rate. At higher doses, dopamine can stimulate beta-1 adrenergic receptors, leading to positive chronotropic (increased heart rate) and inotropic (increased contractility) effects. However, these effects are more pronounced at moderate to high doses, not at low doses.
  • • C. It causes vasoconstriction – Incorrect:
  • • At low doses, dopamine does not cause significant vasoconstriction. It primarily causes vasodilation in the renal and mesenteric vessels. Vasoconstriction occurs at higher doses when dopamine stimulates alpha-adrenergic receptors, which leads to increased blood pressure.
  • • D. It causes hypotension – Incorrect:
  • • At low doses, dopamine typically does not cause hypotension. It may cause a slight increase in blood pressure due to vasodilation in the renal and mesenteric vessels. Hypotension may occur at very low doses or in cases of severe shock, but at low doses, dopamine is more likely to help improve blood flow to the kidneys rather than reduce blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of limb muscle especially in the evening after work. These symptoms improved after edrophonium test. This patient is likely suffering from which one of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that leads to muscle weakness, which often worsens with activity (fatigue) and improves with rest. This condition is caused by antibodies that block or destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing effective muscle contraction.
  • • The edrophonium test (a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which improves muscle strength in myasthenia gravis patients. This improvement is characteristic of MG.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lambert Eaton syndrome – Incorrect:
  • • Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is also a neuromuscular disorder, but it is caused by autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, impairing the release of acetylcholine. The weakness in LEMS is usually more prominent in the proximal muscles (e.g., thighs, shoulders) and tends to improve with muscle use, which is the opposite of myasthenia gravis. The edrophonium test does not show the same improvement as in MG.
  • • C. Bronchial asthma – Incorrect:
  • • Bronchial asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by airway constriction and wheezing due to inflammation and bronchospasm. While asthma can cause shortness of breath and weakness, it does not cause muscle weakness that improves with an edrophonium test. Asthma is unrelated to neuromuscular junction disorders.
  • • D. Guillain-Barré syndrome – Incorrect:
  • • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the peripheral nervous system, typically triggered by an infection. It leads to ascending muscle weakness, which progresses rapidly. While GBS causes weakness, it does not improve with the edrophonium test. The condition is typically characterized by progressive paralysis and sensory disturbances, rather than the fluctuating weakness seen in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: After eating an unknown plant, a child was presented to the emergency with comatose status. The pupil were dilated and skin was dry. Body temperature was raised and the heart rate was high. These signs and symptoms can occur with the intake of which of the following substance?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Dhatura (Datura stramonium) is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties, which can cause delirium, hallucinations, dilated pupils, dry mouth, increased heart rate, elevated body temperature, and skin dryness. The alkaloids in dhatura (e.g., scopolamine, hyoscyamine) inhibit acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to these characteristic toxic effects. In severe cases, dhatura poisoning can result in coma and death due to its systemic effects.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Foxglove – Incorrect:
  • • Foxglove (digitalis) contains compounds called cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to arrhythmias and bradycardia (slow heart rate), not symptoms like dry skin, elevated body temperature, or dilated pupils. The symptoms described are more characteristic of anticholinergic poisoning, not digitalis toxicity.
  • • B. Poppy seeds – Incorrect:
  • • Poppy seeds contain trace amounts of opioid alkaloids (such as morphine and codeine), but they are not known to cause the anticholinergic symptoms of dilated pupils, dry skin, and elevated body temperature. Opioid toxicity would cause miosis (constricted pupils), respiratory depression, and bradycardia, not the signs mentioned in the question.
  • • C. Cannabinoid – Incorrect:
  • • Cannabinoids (such as those found in marijuana) generally cause euphoria, drowsiness, increased heart rate, and conjunctival injection (red eyes), but they do not typically produce the anticholinergic symptoms described. While cannabinoid toxicity can lead to altered mental status, it does not typically cause dilated pupils and dry skin as seen with dhatura poisoning.

questions.text: A farmer is presented to the emergency with garlic odour breathing, pin point pupil and excessive salivary secretion. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating this poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Garlic odor can be a sign of exposure to organophosphates or phosphorus-based pesticides.
  • • Pinpoint pupils (miosis), excessive salivation, sweating, and other cholinergic symptoms (such as diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting) are consistent with cholinergic crisis caused by organophosphate toxicity.
  • • Atropine is the drug of choice for treating organophosphate poisoning because it is a muscarinic antagonist that blocks the effects of excess acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, helping to alleviate symptoms such as bradycardia, salivation, and miosis.
  • • In severe cases, pralidoxime (PAM) may also be used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase, but atropine is the mainstay for managing the cholinergic effects in this situation.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Flumazenil – Incorrect:
  • • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist, used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. It has no role in treating organophosphate poisoning or cholinergic toxicity.
  • • B. Pralidoxime – Incorrect:
  • • Pralidoxime is an acetylcholinesterase reactivator that can be used as an adjunct to atropine in organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the first-line drug. Atropine is the primary treatment to counteract muscarinic symptoms, while pralidoxime is typically used when there is a need to reverse the nicotinic effects (such as muscle weakness) or to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. In this case, atropine is the correct answer.
  • • D. N-acetylcysteine – Incorrect:
  • • N-acetylcysteine is used in acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose to replenish glutathione and prevent liver damage. It has no role in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning or cholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: An elderly male patient developed dementia and was diagnosed as Alzheimer’s disease. Which neurotransmitter level is reduced in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Acetylcholine plays a key role in synaptic transmission in the brain, and its deficiency in Alzheimer’s disease contributes to the cognitive decline and memory impairment seen in these patients.
  • • Cholinesterase inhibitors (such as donepezil) are often used to help increase acetylcholine levels in the brain, improving symptoms or slowing the progression of cognitive decline in Alzheimer's patients.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Dopamine – Incorrect:
  • • Dopamine is associated with movement regulation and is primarily implicated in diseases like Parkinson’s disease and schizophrenia, not Alzheimer's disease. Although dopamine levels can be affected in various neurodegenerative diseases, reduced acetylcholine is the hallmark neurotransmitter deficiency in Alzheimer’s.
  • • B. Serotonin – Incorrect:
  • • Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, appetite, and sleep, and its levels can be altered in disorders like depression and anxiety. While there may be some serotonergic involvement in Alzheimer’s, acetylcholine is the key neurotransmitter that is significantly reduced in Alzheimer's disease.
  • • C. Adrenaline – Incorrect:
  • • Adrenaline (epinephrine) is involved in the fight or flight response and is primarily related to the sympathetic nervous system. It is not specifically involved in Alzheimer’s disease, where the problem lies primarily with acetylcholine in the brain.

questions.text: A deep vein thrombosis patient was started on an anticoagulant therapy. Next day, the patient presented with the features shown in the diagram below. Likely drug implicated for this adverse effect is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Warfarin works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and can lead to a hypercoagulable state initially (before the anticoagulant effect fully kicks in). This can cause thrombosis in small vessels, leading to skin necrosis.
  • • This adverse effect typically occurs within the first few days of treatment and is more common in patients with protein C or S deficiency, as these proteins are natural anticoagulants, and their inhibition by warfarin can cause an increased risk of clot formation.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Heparin – Incorrect:
  • • Heparin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is commonly used in the hospital setting for DVT treatment. It can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), but it does not commonly cause the type of skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin. HIT can lead to thrombosis, but not the same cutaneous symptoms as warfarin.
  • • B. Rivaroxaban – Incorrect:
  • • Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits Factor Xa. While DOACs have their own risk of bleeding and thrombosis, they are not commonly associated with the same skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin.
  • • D. Dabigatran – Incorrect:
  • • Dabigatran is another DOAC, this one inhibiting thrombin (Factor II). While it has anticoagulant effects, it is not associated with skin necrosis or the early hypercoagulable state seen with warfarin. Like rivaroxaban, it does not produce the same complications as warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following hypolipidemic drug acts by inhibition of PCSK-9?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This class of drugs is used in patients with hyperlipidemia, especially those who do not respond adequately to statins or those with familial hypercholesterolemia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Atorvastatin – Incorrect:
  • • Atorvastatin is a statin, which works by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the enzyme responsible for the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis in the liver. It reduces cholesterol production, which in turn leads to increased expression of LDL receptors and decreased LDL cholesterol levels. However, atorvastatin does not work by inhibiting PCSK-9.
  • • C. Ezetimibe – Incorrect:
  • • Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the NPC1L1 protein, which is involved in the absorption of cholesterol from the intestine. By reducing cholesterol absorption, it helps lower total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol levels. However, it does not target PCSK-9.
  • • D. Fenofibrate – Incorrect:
  • • Fenofibrate is a fibrate that primarily acts by activating PPAR-alpha, leading to increased oxidation of fatty acids and reduced triglyceride levels. It can also modestly increase HDL cholesterol but does not affect PCSK-9.

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant patient on warfarin. INR level is 3.Best Course of action would be
questions.correct_answer: D. Stop warfarin switch to heparin
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The best course of action in this case is to stop warfarin and switch to heparin, which is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy. Heparin (both unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin) does not cross the placenta and is safe for the fetus.
  • • Additionally, heparin can provide adequate anticoagulation, and the patient's INR should be monitored while transitioning to heparin therapy.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Add aspirin – Incorrect:
  • • Aspirin is not typically used as a sole anticoagulant in pregnancy, particularly in this case, where the patient is on warfarin and has an elevated INR. Adding aspirin alone is not sufficient for anticoagulation, especially in patients requiring a more effective therapy for conditions like deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
  • • B. Aspirin + Heparin – Incorrect:
  • • While heparin is appropriate for anticoagulation during pregnancy, adding aspirin is typically used in specific conditions like preeclampsia, recurrent pregnancy loss, or for antiplatelet effects in certain cardiovascular conditions. It is not needed in this case, and the priority should be stopping warfarin and starting heparin.
  • • C. Continue warfarin – Incorrect:
  • • Continuing warfarin is not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to the risk of fetal bleeding and teratogenicity. The best approach is to stop warfarin immediately and switch to heparin.

questions.text: Drug useful for ventricular tachycardia
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • IV amiodarone is typically used in emergency settings, especially when VT is hemodynamically unstable or persistent.
  • • It can be administered intravenously in acute situations to rapidly correct the arrhythmia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Oral Amiodarone – Incorrect:
  • • Oral amiodarone is used for chronic management of arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation and for prevention of recurrent ventricular arrhythmias, but it is not suitable for acute management of ventricular tachycardia. In emergencies, the rapid action of IV amiodarone is preferred.
  • • C. IV Beta Blocker – Incorrect:
  • • IV beta blockers are sometimes used for supraventricular tachycardias or to manage atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, but they are not the first-line treatment for ventricular tachycardia. Beta blockers do not have the same efficacy in controlling ventricular arrhythmias compared to amiodarone.
  • • D. Oral Beta Blocker – Incorrect:
  • • Oral beta blockers are used for long-term control of arrhythmias, but they are not effective in the acute management of ventricular tachycardia. They may be helpful in preventing recurrent arrhythmias after the acute episode has been managed, but IV amiodarone is preferred in emergencies.

questions.text: DOC for digitalis induced Ventricular tachycardia is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Lidocaine acts by blocking sodium channels, especially in ischemic or depolarized ventricular tissue, and it suppresses ectopic pacemakers.
  • • It does not increase AV nodal conduction, which is crucial because increasing conduction in digoxin toxicity can worsen the arrhythmia.
  • • Moreover, lidocaine is less likely to depress AV conduction, making it safer in the context of digitalis toxicity.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Reducing dosage of digoxin – Incorrect:
  • • While reducing or stopping digoxin is necessary in toxicity, it is not sufficient alone to treat life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias. Active pharmacologic intervention with lidocaine or other agents is needed in acute settings.
  • • C. Verapamil – Incorrect:
  • • Verapamil, a calcium channel blocker, is contraindicated in digitalis toxicity, as it can worsen heart block and may increase digoxin levels, making arrhythmias worse.
  • • D. Beta blockers – Incorrect:
  • • Beta blockers can slow AV conduction and may help in some supraventricular arrhythmias, but they are not preferred in digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias, and can also worsen bradyarrhythmias or heart block associated with digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a late inward sodium channel blocker?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In ischemic conditions, increased late sodium influx leads to sodium and calcium overload inside myocardial cells.
  • • This intracellular calcium overload increases diastolic wall tension, worsens myocardial oxygen demand, and impairs relaxation (diastolic dysfunction).
  • • Ranolazine, by blocking late Na? channels, reduces calcium overload indirectly (via the Na?/Ca²? exchanger) and thus improves myocardial relaxation and reduces oxygen consumption, without affecting heart rate or blood pressure.
  • • This mechanism makes ranolazine especially useful in chronic stable angina, particularly when conventional therapies are not well tolerated.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Ivabradine – Incorrect:
  • • Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial (SA) node, leading to heart rate reduction without affecting contractility or blood pressure. It does not block late sodium channels.
  • • C. Trimetazidine – Incorrect:
  • • Trimetazidine is a metabolic modulator used in angina. It shifts myocardial energy metabolism from fatty acid oxidation to glucose oxidation, which is more oxygen-efficient. It does not affect sodium channels.
  • • D. Fasudil – Incorrect:
  • • Fasudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor used in pulmonary hypertension and cerebral vasospasm. It works by causing vasodilation but has no effect on sodium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drug is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Pulmonary toxicity is one of the most dangerous adverse effects of amiodarone, and it can present as interstitial pneumonitis, pulmonary fibrosis, or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • • In patients with pre-existing interstitial lung disease (ILD), the risk of amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity is significantly increased, and its use can worsen respiratory function.
  • • Therefore, amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with ILD or significant pulmonary disease.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Sotalol – Incorrect:
  • • Sotalol is also a Class III antiarrhythmic but lacks the pulmonary toxicity seen with amiodarone. It has beta-blocker activity and is generally safe in patients without significant cardiac or renal contraindications. It is not contraindicated in ILD.
  • • C. Quinidine – Incorrect:
  • • Quinidine is a Class Ia antiarrhythmic. Its adverse effects include QT prolongation, cinchonism, and GI disturbances, but not pulmonary toxicity. It is not contraindicated in ILD.
  • • D. Lignocaine (Lidocaine) – Incorrect:
  • • Lignocaine is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic, used mainly for ventricular arrhythmias, especially in emergency settings. It does not cause lung toxicity and is safe in patients with ILD.

questions.text: A patient with ECG changes of MI underwent CABG. What will you add on to the list along with aspirin
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Aspirin is a cornerstone of antiplatelet therapy.
  • • P2Y12 inhibitors (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) are added to aspirin in post-MI patients, even after CABG, especially when there is concern for graft patency or ongoing risk of thrombosis.
  • • Clinical guidelines recommend aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor as dual therapy in patients with MI, particularly those undergoing PCI or CABG depending on individual bleeding and thrombotic risk.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. PDE 5 inhibitor – Incorrect:
  • • Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) are used for erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. They have no role in post-MI or CABG antiplatelet management, and can be dangerous when combined with nitrates due to risk of severe hypotension.
  • • B. Dabigatran – Incorrect:
  • • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (anticoagulant) used for atrial fibrillation and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prevention. It is not used in the standard treatment of MI post-CABG unless there's a separate indication for anticoagulation (e.g., AF).
  • • D. PDE 3 inhibitor – Incorrect:
  • • PDE-3 inhibitors (e.g., milrinone, cilostazol) are used in heart failure or intermittent claudication, not for post-MI antiplatelet therapy. They do not replace or enhance the effects of aspirin and are not indicated after CABG for MI.

questions.text: A women used aspirin for arthritis for pain relief for years. Later she developed intestinal bleed which occurs due to inhibition of
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, COX-1 normally helps produce protective prostaglandins that maintain mucosal blood flow, mucus secretion, and bicarbonate production.
  • • Chronic use of aspirin inhibits COX-1, leading to reduced prostaglandin synthesis, which compromises the protective mucosal barrier.
  • • Additionally, inhibition of thromboxane A? (produced by platelets via COX-1) reduces platelet aggregation, increasing the risk of bleeding, especially from areas like the stomach and intestines that are already vulnerable due to mucosal injury.
  • • Therefore, inhibition of thromboxane A? contributes to intestinal bleeding by impairing platelet aggregation and hemostasis.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Leukotriene – Incorrect:
  • • Leukotrienes are products of the lipoxygenase pathway, not the cyclooxygenase pathway.
  • • Aspirin does not inhibit leukotriene synthesis. In fact, shunting of arachidonic acid metabolism toward leukotriene production may cause bronchospasm in aspirin-sensitive asthma, but not GI bleeding.
  • • C. Bradykinin – Incorrect:
  • • Bradykinin is a vasoactive peptide involved in pain, inflammation, and vascular permeability. It is not directly affected by aspirin and does not play a key role in mucosal protection or bleeding related to NSAIDs.
  • • D. Hageman factor – Incorrect:
  • • Hageman factor (Factor XII) is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Aspirin does not affect this clotting factor, and it is not implicated in the GI bleeding associated with NSAID use.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of apixaban?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Factor Xa is responsible for converting prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa).
  • • Thrombin then converts fibrinogen to fibrin, leading to clot formation.
  • • By inhibiting Factor Xa, apixaban reduces thrombin generation and prevents the formation of fibrin clots.
  • • Apixaban is used in conditions like:
  • • Atrial fibrillation (to prevent stroke),
  • • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT),
  • • Pulmonary embolism (PE),
  • • And for thromboprophylaxis after orthopedic surgery.
  • • It is a direct-acting oral anticoagulant (DOAC) and does not require routine INR monitoring, unlike warfarin.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor inhibitors – Incorrect:
  • • This refers to drugs like clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor, which inhibit the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, preventing aggregation.
  • • These are antiplatelet agents, not anticoagulants like apixaban.
  • • C. Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitors – Incorrect:
  • • Drugs like abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban block the GPIIb/IIIa receptor on platelets, inhibiting fibrinogen binding and aggregation.
  • • These are used primarily in acute coronary syndromes, and again are antiplatelet, not anticoagulant drugs.
  • • D. Adenosine reuptake inhibitors – Incorrect:
  • • Dipyridamole is an example, which increases adenosine levels and inhibits platelet function.
  • • It is also an antiplatelet agent used sometimes in stroke prevention.

questions.text: A hypertensive woman who wants to conceive. Which medicine needs to be stopped?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Fetal renal dysgenesis
  • • Oligohydramnios
  • • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • • Skull hypoplasia
  • • Neonatal renal failure and death
  • • Because of these serious fetal risks, ACE inhibitors must be discontinued in any hypertensive woman who is planning to conceive or becomes pregnant. They are classified as Category D (positive evidence of human fetal risk) in pregnancy.
  • • Safe alternatives during pregnancy include:
  • • Labetalol
  • • Methyldopa
  • • Nifedipine
  • • Hydralazine (typically in acute settings)
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. CCB (Calcium Channel Blockers) – Incorrect:
  • • Nifedipine and other dihydropyridine CCBs are generally safe in pregnancy and are commonly used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.
  • • C. Hydralazine – Incorrect:
  • • Hydralazine is a vasodilator that is safe and effective in pregnancy, especially in managing acute severe hypertension.
  • • D. Metoprolol – Incorrect:
  • • While beta-blockers can have some fetal effects (e.g. intrauterine growth restriction), selective beta-1 blockers like metoprolol are often considered relatively safe in pregnancy, especially if alternatives are not tolerated. However, labetalol is usually preferred.

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital after consuming 8 tablets of 0.25 mg digoxin. His ECG shows ST depression and QT changes. What should be the initial management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • History of ingestion of 8 tablets of 0.25 mg digoxin (total dose = 2 mg, which is toxic),
  • • ECG changes consistent with digoxin effect (e.g., scooped ST depression, QT shortening, and possible arrhythmias).
  • • The first-line and most effective treatment for life-threatening or severe digoxin toxicity is Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Digoxin immune Fab), which:
  • • Bind to digoxin in the blood,
  • • Form a complex that is excreted by the kidneys,
  • • Rapidly reverse toxic cardiac and systemic effects.
  • • Indications for Digoxin immune Fab include:
  • • Life-threatening arrhythmias,
  • • Significant hyperkalemia,
  • • Ingestion of a large amount of digoxin,
  • • High serum digoxin level in a symptomatic patient.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Lignocaine – Incorrect:
  • • Lignocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that may be used in some ventricular arrhythmias, but it is not the initial or definitive treatment for digoxin toxicity. It is secondary to Fab fragments.
  • • C. Intravenous Adenosine – Incorrect:
  • • Adenosine is used to treat paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). It is contraindicated in digoxin-induced arrhythmias, especially atrial tachycardia with block, as it may precipitate complete heart block or ventricular fibrillation.
  • • D. Sublingual nitroglycerine – Incorrect:
  • • Nitroglycerine is used for angina and coronary artery spasm, not for digoxin toxicity. It has no role in treating digoxin overdose.

questions.text: Drugs providing relief from Cardiac remodelling and increasing longevity ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism: In chronic heart failure, sympathetic overactivity contributes to progressive cardiac remodeling and deterioration.
  • • Beta-blockers like metoprolol reduce heart rate, decrease myocardial oxygen demand, and block the harmful effects of chronic catecholamine stimulation, which slows or reverses cardiac remodeling.
  • • They also reduce mortality and hospitalizations in heart failure patients (as shown in trials like MERIT-HF).
  • • Other beta-blockers with proven mortality benefit in heart failure include:
  • • Bisoprolol
  • • Carvedilol
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Torsemide – Incorrect:
  • • Torsemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not prevent remodeling or improve survival. It provides symptomatic benefit only.
  • • C. Prazosin – Incorrect:
  • • Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker used for hypertension and sometimes BPH. It is not used in heart failure due to lack of benefit on mortality and may cause hypotension.
  • • D. Furosemide – Incorrect:
  • • Like torsemide, furosemide is a loop diuretic that helps manage fluid overload in heart failure. However, it has no effect on cardiac remodeling or survival.

questions.text: Sacubitril used in congestive heart failure works by-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of Action: Neprilysin is an enzyme that breaks down natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin—all of which have beneficial effects in heart failure (vasodilation, natriuresis, diuresis, and inhibition of cardiac fibrosis and remodeling).
  • • Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin, thereby increasing the levels of these beneficial peptides, which helps to reduce preload and afterload, improve cardiac output, and slow progression of heart failure.
  • • When combined with valsartan (as in sacubitril/valsartan, brand name Entresto), the drug also blocks the harmful RAAS pathway, offering dual benefit:
  • • Natriuretic peptide enhancement (via sacubitril)
  • • RAAS inhibition (via valsartan)
  • • Clinical trials like PARADIGM-HF showed this combination reduces mortality and hospitalizations in heart failure patients better than ACE inhibitors alone.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Renin agonist – Incorrect:
  • • Sacubitril does not act on renin directly. A renin agonist would enhance the RAAS pathway, which is harmful in heart failure.
  • • C. Aldosterone inhibitor – Incorrect:
  • • Aldosterone inhibitors (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) do help in heart failure but sacubitril is not one. It acts via neprilysin inhibition.
  • • D. Endothelin agonist – Incorrect:
  • • Endothelin agonists cause vasoconstriction, which would worsen heart failure. Sacubitril does not act on the endothelin system.

questions.text: In which of the following drugs coagulation monitoring is required?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • UFH has unpredictable pharmacokinetics due to variable binding to plasma proteins, leading to variable anticoagulant responses among individuals.
  • • Monitoring ensures the dose is therapeutic (not too low to be ineffective, or too high causing bleeding).
  • • aPTT is usually maintained at 1.5–2.5 times the normal value during therapy.
  • • UFH is commonly used in:
  • • Acute coronary syndromes
  • • Venous thromboembolism
  • • During and after surgeries requiring anticoagulation
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Dabigatran – Incorrect:
  • • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (NOAC).
  • • It has predictable pharmacokinetics and does not require routine coagulation monitoring.
  • • In certain emergencies or renal impairment, specialized assays (e.g., TT, ECT) may be used, but routine monitoring is not needed.
  • • B. Enoxaparin – Incorrect:
  • • Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) with predictable dose-response.
  • • Routine monitoring is not required in most patients, though anti-Xa level monitoring may be done in pregnancy, renal failure, or obesity.
  • • C. Fondaparinux – Incorrect:
  • • Fondaparinux is a synthetic factor Xa inhibitor with stable pharmacokinetics.
  • • It also does not require routine coagulation monitoring under normal conditions.

questions.text: Which drug acts on letter mentioned 2?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. It blocks renin's action at this early step, thus inhibiting the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, and subsequently reducing the formation of angiotensin II and aldosterone downstream. This leads to:
  • • Vasodilation
  • • Reduced sodium and water retention
  • • Lowered blood pressure
  • • Since site 2 refers to the renin action point, Aliskiren is the drug that acts at that site.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Enalapril – Incorrect:
  • • Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor.
  • • It inhibits the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (site 3 in the typical RAAS diagram), not site 2.
  • • B. Telmisartan – Incorrect:
  • • Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB).
  • • It blocks the action of angiotensin II on AT1 receptors (site 4 in the pathway), not site 2.
  • • D. Eplerenone – Incorrect:
  • • Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist.
  • • It acts at the level of aldosterone receptors in the kidney (site 5 in the pathway), not at site 2.

questions.text: Find out the site of actions of thiazide diuretics
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of Action of Thiazide Diuretics:
  • • Thiazides (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone) inhibit the Na?/Cl? symporter in the early distal convoluted tubule.
  • • This results in increased excretion of sodium and chloride, leading to increased water excretion.
  • • Also causes mild potassium loss and increased calcium reabsorption.
  • • Clinical uses include:
  • • Hypertension
  • • Edema due to heart failure or liver/kidney disease
  • • Nephrolithiasis due to hypercalciuria
  • • Why other options are incorrect: A. Site 1 – Incorrect:
  • • Refers to the proximal convoluted tubule.
  • • This is the site of action of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide, not thiazides.
  • • B. Site 2 – Incorrect:
  • • Refers to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.
  • • This is the site of action of loop diuretics like furosemide.
  • • D. Site 4 – Incorrect:
  • • Refers to the collecting duct, where potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone, amiloride) act.

questions.text: At a high altitude of 3000 m, a person complains of breathlessnes. All of the following can be used for management of this person except:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Correct management strategies include:
  • • Oxygen supplementation (Option B): Increases arterial oxygen levels and is one of the most effective immediate interventions for high-altitude illness.
  • • Immediate descent (Option C): The most definitive and life-saving measure in moderate to severe cases. Removing the person from the hypoxic environment is essential.
  • • Acetazolamide (Option D): A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for prophylaxis and treatment of AMS. It promotes acclimatization by causing a mild metabolic acidosis that stimulates ventilation.
  • • Why Option A is Incorrect (and thus the correct answer to the question): Intravenous digoxin is not indicated in the management of high-altitude illness.
  • • Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and certain arrhythmias, but has no role in treating hypoxia or altitude-related symptoms.
  • • Its use could be harmful due to potential toxicity, especially in a setting of dehydration or electrolyte disturbances common at high altitude.

questions.text: Which of the following is an orally acting direct Xa inhibitor
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Used in stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • • It is part of the class of drugs known as DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants).
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Agartaban — Incorrect:
  • • Likely a misspelling or confusion with Argatroban, which is a direct thrombin inhibitor (not Xa inhibitor) and is administered intravenously, not orally.
  • • C. Dabigatran — Incorrect:
  • • A direct thrombin (Factor IIa) inhibitor, not a Xa inhibitor.
  • • It is orally active, but does not inhibit Factor Xa.
  • • D. Bivalirudin — Incorrect:
  • • A parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor used mainly during percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI).
  • • Not a Xa inhibitor and not orally administered.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug used to treat SIADH
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Tolvaptan is a vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by:
  • • Blocking the action of ADH in the renal collecting ducts.
  • • Promoting free water excretion (aquaresis) without loss of sodium or other electrolytes.
  • • Increasing serum sodium levels — which is crucial in treating SIADH.
  • • Tolvaptan is orally active and specifically indicated for euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia, such as that caused by SIADH.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Desmopressin — Incorrect:
  • • A synthetic analog of ADH, used to treat diabetes insipidus and certain bleeding disorders.
  • • It worsens SIADH by increasing water retention.
  • • C. Von Willebrand factor — Incorrect:
  • • A clotting protein, used in von Willebrand disease and hemophilia A.
  • • Has no role in water or sodium balance or the management of SIADH.
  • • D. Terlipressin — Incorrect:
  • • A vasopressin analog used in variceal bleeding and hepatorenal syndrome.
  • • Like desmopressin, it would exacerbate SIADH by increasing water retention.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-dyslipidemic drug work by stimulating PPAR alpha ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of action of Gemfibrozil (via PPAR-α activation):
  • • Increases expression of lipoprotein lipase, enhancing the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins.
  • • Increases fatty acid oxidation in liver and muscle.
  • • Reduces hepatic secretion of VLDL.
  • • Moderately increases HDL cholesterol.
  • • PPAR-α activation is particularly effective for lowering triglycerides and is beneficial in patients with metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes with dyslipidemia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Simvastatin — Incorrect:
  • • It is a statin, which works by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis.
  • • It does not act on PPAR-α.
  • • C. Ezetimibe — Incorrect:
  • • Inhibits NPC1L1 transporter in the small intestine, reducing cholesterol absorption.
  • • Has no effect on PPAR-α.
  • • D. Colestipol — Incorrect:
  • • A bile acid sequestrant that works in the intestine by binding bile acids and promoting their excretion.
  • • This indirectly reduces LDL cholesterol but has no interaction with PPAR-α.

questions.text: Drug acting on K+ channels include
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Nitrate-like action – It donates nitric oxide (NO), leading to vasodilation, especially of venous vessels.
  • • Potassium channel opener – It opens ATP-sensitive K? channels (KATP channels) in vascular smooth muscle.
  • • This causes hyperpolarization, reducing calcium influx, leading to arteriolar vasodilation.
  • • By acting on both venous and arterial systems, nicorandil:
  • • Reduces preload (via venodilation).
  • • Reduces afterload (via arteriolar dilation).
  • • Improves coronary blood flow, helpful in angina pectoris.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Spironolactone — Incorrect:
  • • It is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist.
  • • Acts on the mineralocorticoid receptor in the distal nephron, not on K? channels.
  • • B. Amiloride — Incorrect:
  • • Also a potassium-sparing diuretic, but works by blocking epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the renal collecting duct.
  • • It reduces sodium reabsorption, thereby retaining potassium, but does not directly act on K? channels.
  • • D. Methyldopa — Incorrect:
  • • It is a centrally acting alpha-2 agonist, used to treat hypertension, especially in pregnancy.
  • • It does not interact with potassium channels.

questions.text: Iv mannitol is used for the treatment of?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In acute congestive glaucoma, there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), which can threaten vision. IV mannitol:
  • • Increases plasma osmolality.
  • • Draws fluid out of the eye (aqueous humor) into the bloodstream.
  • • Rapidly reduces intraocular pressure.
  • • Thus, mannitol is particularly effective in acute angle-closure glaucoma before surgical intervention or more definitive therapy.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B. Pulmonary edema — Incorrect:
  • • Mannitol draws fluid into the intravascular space, which can worsen pulmonary edema due to increased preload and fluid overload.
  • • It is contraindicated in patients with heart failure or pulmonary congestion.
  • • C. Acute renal failure — Incorrect (partially):
  • • Previously used in pre-renal or early renal failure to maintain urine flow.
  • • However, it is not routinely used now because it can worsen fluid overload and has no proven benefit in established acute kidney injury.
  • • D. CHF (Congestive Heart Failure) — Incorrect:
  • • Mannitol increases plasma volume, which can exacerbate heart failure symptoms like dyspnea and edema.
  • • It is contraindicated in CHF.
