questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with road traffic accident. This patient has raised intracranial pressure without intracranial hematoma. Which of the following drug is preferred for management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mannitol is the drug of choice for managing elevated ICP because it not only reduces swelling but also improves cerebral perfusion.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A. Prednisolone — Incorrect:
  • • Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that can be used to reduce inflammation in cases of brain swelling, but it is not first-line for reducing intracranial pressure.
  • • It is more commonly used for spinal cord injury or brain tumors, but not as effective as mannitol in acute traumatic brain injury with raised ICP.
  • • B. Furosemide — Incorrect:
  • • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can help in reducing fluid volume, but it is not as effective as mannitol for reducing ICP.
  • • It may not have the same potent osmotically driven action that mannitol has in managing brain edema.
  • • D. Glycerol — Incorrect:
  • • Glycerol is another osmotic agent, but it is less commonly used than mannitol for controlling elevated ICP in traumatic brain injury.
  • • It has a weaker effect on reducing ICP compared to mannitol.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of PGI2?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Inhibits platelet aggregation (A):
  • • PGI2 prevents the aggregation of platelets, which is crucial in the prevention of blood clot formation. It acts as an antiplatelet agent, opposing the effects of thromboxane A2 (TXA2), which promotes platelet aggregation.
  • • Vasodilatation (B):
  • • PGI2 causes vasodilation by relaxing the smooth muscle cells in blood vessels. This helps in reducing blood pressure and improving blood flow.
  • • Pyrogenic (C):
  • • PGI2 also has pyrogenic properties, meaning it can raise body temperature, contributing to the body's response to fever.
  • • Why the other options are incomplete: While each individual function listed (A, B, and C) is true for PGI2, D encompasses all of the effects that PGI2 has, making it the most comprehensive and correct answer.

questions.text: Analgesic drug in renal failure and patient on dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Acetaminophen (D) is the preferred analgesic in these cases because:
  • • It is primarily metabolized in the liver, and only a small amount is excreted unchanged by the kidneys.
  • • It does not typically cause further renal damage or accumulate to dangerous levels in patients with renal failure.
  • • It is considered safe for short-term use in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) or those undergoing dialysis.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: Indomethacin (A):
  • • Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), which can worsen kidney function, especially in renal failure. NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow, potentially leading to further kidney damage.
  • • Avoid in renal failure or dialysis patients.
  • • Naproxen (B):
  • • Like indomethacin, naproxen is an NSAID that can also impair kidney function. It should be avoided in patients with renal impairment due to the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI) and fluid retention.
  • • Diclofenac (C):
  • • Diclofenac is another NSAID that poses similar risks to renal function. It can cause nephrotoxicity and fluid retention, which is particularly harmful in patients with renal failure or those on dialysis.

questions.text: Drug of choice in paracetamol overdose is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • N-acetylcysteine (A) works as an antidote by replenishing glutathione, a substance in the liver that helps detoxify toxic metabolites of paracetamol.
  • • Paracetamol is metabolized in the liver to a non-toxic form but can also be metabolized to a toxic metabolite (NAPQI), which can cause severe liver damage.
  • • NAC helps to detoxify NAPQI, thus preventing liver damage and improving the prognosis of the overdose.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: Dopamine (B):
  • • Dopamine is used in cases of shock and severe hypotension to improve blood flow to vital organs, but it has no role in paracetamol overdose.
  • • Hydralazine (C):
  • • Hydralazine is a vasodilator primarily used to treat hypertension and heart failure. It does not address the toxic effects of paracetamol overdose.
  • • Furosemide (D):
  • • Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension. It does not help with paracetamol toxicity and may even worsen renal function in overdose situations.

questions.text: A female patient was having pain in her great toe(metatarsal phalangeal ) with swelling and redness present over it. Her uric acid level high. She was treated with a proper drug therapy and her symptoms subsided. The drug that has reduced her uric acid level must act .by
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors like allopurinol and febuxostat are used to reduce uric acid levels by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the final step in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. By inhibiting this enzyme, the production of uric acid is decreased.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: HGPRT inhibition (B):
  • • HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase) is an enzyme involved in purine salvage pathways. Deficiency of HGPRT leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, not a common treatment mechanism for gout. In gout management, reducing uric acid production is typically done through xanthine oxidase inhibition.
  • • Aldose reductase inhibitor (C):
  • • Aldose reductase inhibitors are primarily used in the management of diabetic complications like diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, not in gout or uric acid reduction.
  • • Cytochrome oxidase inhibitor (D):
  • • Cytochrome oxidase inhibitors affect mitochondrial respiration and are typically not involved in the treatment of gout or uric acid metabolism.

questions.text: A female patient was having pain in her great toe(metatarsal joint)with swelling and redness present over it, She was treated with a proper drug therapy but her uric acid still coming out to be high. Which of the following drug can be given for fast elimination of drug from he body
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Probenecid is the correct choice because it is a uricosuric drug that increases the renal excretion of uric acid. It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubules of the kidneys, thereby helping to eliminate excess uric acid more efficiently and lower the serum uric acid levels.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: Allopurinol (A):
  • • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used to reduce uric acid production. It is not a drug that helps to eliminate uric acid fast but instead reduces its production over time. It is useful for chronic gout management, not for rapid elimination of uric acid.
  • • Febuxostat (B):
  • • Febuxostat is another xanthine oxidase inhibitor like allopurinol, and its action is similar in reducing uric acid production. While it helps manage gout, it does not promote rapid elimination of uric acid from the body.
  • • Colchicine (C):
  • • Colchicine is used to treat acute gout attacks by reducing inflammation. It does not have a direct effect on uric acid elimination from the body. It helps with the symptoms but not with speeding up the excretion of uric acid.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. After 2 years, he developed blurring of vision and was found to have corneal opacity. Which drug is most likely to cause this?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the other options are incorrect: Sulfasalazine (A):
  • • Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. It can cause photosensitivity and skin reactions, but it is not commonly associated with corneal opacity or vision issues.
  • • Methotrexate (C):
  • • Methotrexate is another DMARD commonly used for rheumatoid arthritis. While it has several side effects like liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, and gastrointestinal distress, it is not associated with corneal opacity. Vision issues are not a typical side effect of methotrexate.
  • • Leflunomide (D):
  • • Leflunomide is also a DMARD used for rheumatoid arthritis, and while it can have side effects such as liver toxicity and diarrhea, it is not linked to corneal opacity or visual disturbances.

questions.text: True about colchicine is

options.label: C
options.text: Useful in uric acid lowering therapy

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A - Acts by neutrophil recruitment:
  • • Colchicine inhibits the migration of neutrophils to the site of inflammation. It does so by disrupting the microtubules, which are important for cell motility and chemotaxis (movement toward the inflammatory site). This prevents neutrophils from accumulating in the joints, which is a key step in the inflammatory process of gout.
  • • B - Causes metaphase arrest:
  • • Colchicine also disrupts microtubule formation and arrests mitosis at metaphase. This mechanism is responsible for its antimitotic effects, which contribute to its ability to reduce inflammation. The inhibition of microtubules prevents the normal process of cell division, which is why colchicine can cause metaphase arrest.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: C - Useful in uric acid lowering therapy:
  • • While colchicine is effective in treating acute gout attacks, it does not lower uric acid levels. Uric acid-lowering therapy typically involves drugs like allopurinol, febuxostat, or probenecid. Colchicine primarily works by reducing inflammation and pain during an acute gout flare, not by lowering uric acid.

questions.text: Colchicine mechanism of action in gout?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Decrease neutrophil migration:
  • • Colchicine inhibits microtubule polymerization, which interferes with the ability of neutrophils to migrate to sites of inflammation. In gout, uric acid crystals accumulate in the joints, leading to intense inflammation. By reducing neutrophil migration, colchicine reduces the inflammatory response and the pain associated with gout flare-ups.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B - Purine metabolism inhibition:
  • • Purine metabolism inhibition is the mechanism of action of drugs like allopurinol and febuxostat, which lower uric acid levels in the blood. Colchicine does not affect purine metabolism directly.
  • • C - Pyrimidine metabolism inhibition:
  • • Pyrimidine metabolism inhibition is not related to colchicine's mechanism. This mechanism is more relevant to drugs like methotrexate.
  • • D - Uric acid excretion increases:
  • • Colchicine does not directly increase uric acid excretion. Drugs like probenecid or lesinurad work by increasing uric acid excretion, but colchicine's action is focused on reducing the inflammatory response to uric acid crystals rather than altering its excretion.

questions.text: Which one of the following drug is useful for medical closure of patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — Alprostadil:
  • • Alprostadil is a prostaglandin E1 analog used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in cases of cyanotic congenital heart defects that require ductal patency for survival, not for closure.
  • • C — Mefenamic acid:
  • • Mefenamic acid is another NSAID, but it is not commonly used for PDA closure. Indomethacin is preferred because it is more effective in this context.
  • • D — Paracetamol:
  • • Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is used for pain relief and fever reduction but does not have any significant effect on closing the patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Anti-epileptic drug of choice for hypsarrhythmia is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • ACTH works by stimulating the adrenal glands to produce corticosteroids (like cortisol), which help in reducing the frequency and severity of spasms. It is considered the first-line treatment for infantile spasms in cases of hypsarrhythmia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Phenobarbitone:
  • • While phenobarbitone is an anticonvulsant, it is not the first-line treatment for infantile spasms or hypsarrhythmia. It may be used in certain cases, but ACTH is preferred.
  • • B — Phenytoin:
  • • Phenytoin is another anticonvulsant, but it is not effective in treating infantile spasms associated with hypsarrhythmia.
  • • D — Carbamazepine:
  • • Carbamazepine is used for focal seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures, but it is not effective for infantile spasms or hypsarrhythmia.

questions.text: A female developed pain and insect crawling like sensation on legs at night which is relieved by shaking her legs. Which of the following is drug of choice for this condition?

A Patient presented with vomiting and was treated with an anti emetic agent. Later this patient presented with abnormal movement and posture which of the following agent to be used to counter this problem
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract these extrapyramidal symptoms by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the brain. It helps relieve symptoms like tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — Levodopa:
  • • Levodopa is a dopamine precursor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but is not typically used to treat drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms caused by antiemetic agents. Benzhexol is a more appropriate option for this condition.
  • • C — Haloperidol:
  • • Haloperidol is a dopamine antagonist, and it is not suitable for counteracting extrapyramidal symptoms caused by dopamine antagonists. In fact, it can worsen these symptoms because it is an antipsychotic that blocks dopamine receptors.
  • • D — Cyproheptadine:
  • • Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic properties, often used for conditions like allergic reactions or serotonin syndrome, but it is not effective in treating extrapyramidal symptoms caused by antiemetics.

questions.text: Which of the following drug cause maximum prolactin secretion?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Clozapine:
  • • Clozapine, another atypical antipsychotic, has a lower propensity to increase prolactin levels compared to risperidone. Clozapine works through a combination of receptor antagonism, but it has less of an effect on prolactin secretion.
  • • C — Aripiprazole:
  • • Aripiprazole is a partial dopamine agonist and has a minimal effect on prolactin secretion. In fact, it is one of the antipsychotics with the least impact on prolactin levels because it partially activates D2 receptors.
  • • D — Ziprasidone:
  • • Ziprasidone is another atypical antipsychotic, but like aripiprazole, it has a relatively low risk of increasing prolactin levels compared to risperidone. Ziprasidone’s primary mechanism is similar to other antipsychotics but without a significant impact on prolactin secretion.

questions.text: A patient was recently started on Fluphenazine. Few weeks later, he developed tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia and excessive salivation. First line of management for this patient is ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The first-line treatment for drug-induced parkinsonism is the use of anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl. These drugs restore the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the brain, reducing the motor symptoms associated with parkinsonism.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Selegiline:
  • • Selegiline is a MAO-B inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. However, it is not typically used for drug-induced parkinsonism, as it acts on the dopaminergic system and may not effectively address the extrapyramidal symptoms caused by antipsychotic medications.
  • • C — Pramipexole:
  • • Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist used in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. While it could theoretically help with parkinsonism, it is not the first-line treatment for drug-induced parkinsonism caused by antipsychotics. Moreover, dopamine agonists may worsen psychosis in patients on antipsychotic medications.
  • • D — Amantadine:
  • • Amantadine can be used for Parkinson's disease and drug-induced parkinsonism, but it is generally not considered the first-line treatment. Anticholinergics like trihexyphenidyl are more commonly used initially for this type of side effect.

questions.text: A patient received Halothane and developed increased body temperature and muscle rigidity. Administration of which of the following drug can increase the risk of present condition
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that can precipitate or worsen malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals. It causes excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to muscle contraction, rigidity, and heat production. This can exacerbate the condition and lead to a lethal outcome if not treated promptly.
  • • Management of Malignant Hyperthermia: Dantrolene is the treatment of choice for MH. It works by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, effectively reversing the muscle rigidity and hyperthermia.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Dantrolene:
  • • Dantrolene is not a risk factor for malignant hyperthermia. In fact, it is the drug of choice for managing MH. It blocks calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and is essential in treating this condition.
  • • B — D-Tubocurarine:
  • • D-Tubocurarine is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. While it can cause muscle paralysis during surgery, it does not typically trigger malignant hyperthermia. It does not increase the risk of this condition.
  • • D — Atropine:
  • • Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used to treat bradycardia and does not have a role in the pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia. It does not increase the risk of this condition.

questions.text: A patient is on metronidazole. Co- administration of which of the following to be avoided
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Alcohol should be avoided when a patient is taking metronidazole, as this combination can lead to a disulfiram-like reaction. The reaction involves symptoms like nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache, and tachycardia when alcohol is consumed during metronidazole therapy.
  • • The disulfiram-like reaction occurs because metronidazole inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for breaking down acetaldehyde, a by-product of alcohol metabolism. This leads to an accumulation of acetaldehyde, which causes the unpleasant symptoms.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — MAO inhibitors:
  • • MAO inhibitors (Monoamine oxidase inhibitors) can interact with a variety of drugs, but there is no direct contraindication with metronidazole. However, it's always important to consider potential interactions with other medications.
  • • B — Grapefruit juice:
  • • Grapefruit juice can interact with some medications by inhibiting CYP450 enzymes (like CYP3A4), but metronidazole is not significantly metabolized by this enzyme. Therefore, grapefruit juice does not have a significant interaction with metronidazole.
  • • D — Phentolamine:
  • • Phentolamine, an alpha-adrenergic antagonist, does not have a known interaction with metronidazole. There is no contraindication for using them together, and phentolamine is generally used in situations such as managing hypertension or pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A opioid patient presents with symptoms of respiratory depression, treated with……
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Naloxone is typically administered in cases of acute opioid overdose, especially when symptoms like respiratory depression, sedation, or hypotension occur.
  • • It can be given via intravenous (IV), intramuscular (IM), or subcutaneous (SC) routes, and there are also intranasal formulations available.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — Naltrexone:
  • • Naltrexone is another opioid antagonist, but it is used more for long-term maintenance in opioid use disorder (OUD) rather than for acute overdose. It helps prevent relapse by blocking opioid effects.
  • • C — Methadone:
  • • Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist used to treat opioid addiction (as part of maintenance therapy). It is not used to treat opioid overdose but rather to manage opioid withdrawal symptoms and reduce cravings.
  • • D — Flumazenil:
  • • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist, used for benzodiazepine overdoses, not for opioid overdoses. It would not be effective for treating respiratory depression caused by opioids.

questions.text: A patient of biliary colic presented to hospital. Intern gave an injection and the pain worsened. Which is the most likely injection given?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Morphine is a strong opioid analgesic often used to relieve pain. However, in the case of biliary colic, morphine can increase sphincter of Oddi tone, leading to worsening of the pain. The sphincter of Oddi is a muscular valve that controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum. When morphine causes it to contract, it can increase pressure in the biliary tract, worsening the pain associated with biliary colic.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — Diclofenac:
  • • Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). NSAIDs, like diclofenac, are typically used for pain relief in biliary colic and are less likely to increase the pressure in the bile ducts compared to opioids. Therefore, it would not worsen the pain in the same way morphine would.
  • • C — Nefopam:
  • • Nefopam is a non-opioid analgesic with a different mechanism of action than opioids. It is also less likely to affect the sphincter of Oddi and would not worsen the pain in biliary colic.
  • • D — Etoricoxib:
  • • Etoricoxib is another NSAID, like diclofenac, and works by inhibiting COX-2. It would also not cause worsening of biliary colic pain as opioids do. NSAIDs can provide effective pain relief without causing increased pressure in the bile ducts.

questions.text: TCA toxicity, ECG changes with broad QRS complex and right axis deviation. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice for TCA-induced cardiac toxicity. It works by alkalizing the blood and increasing the pH, which can reverse the sodium channel blockade caused by the TCA, thereby improving conduction and narrowing the QRS complex. This also helps to correct acidosis, which is a potential consequence of TCA toxicity.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — Quinidine:
  • • Quinidine is a class 1A antiarrhythmic used to treat arrhythmias, but it is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity. In fact, quinidine can exacerbate the cardiotoxicity associated with TCAs by further blocking sodium channels.
  • • C — Physostigmine:
  • • Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that can be used to treat anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., due to antihistamines or atropine). However, it is not effective for TCA toxicity and does not address the cardiac effects caused by TCAs.
  • • D — Lignocaine:
  • • Lignocaine (lidocaine) is an antiarrhythmic used for ventricular arrhythmias, but it is not effective for TCA toxicity. In fact, lidocaine may not reverse the conduction abnormalities caused by TCA overdose and may even worsen the situation.

questions.text: A 38 yr old college professor suffering from depression comes to you with complaints of unable to get involved in process of intercourse with his wife. Which of the following anti depressant is best to be prescribed to him

These side effects could potentially worsen the patient’s complaints of sexual dysfunction.

It can also be effective in treating depression but may cause sexual dysfunction as a side effect, particularly at higher doses. Like SSRIs, venlafaxine may lead to reduced libido or other sexual issues, which would not be ideal for this patient.

While TCAs can be effective in treating depression, they are more likely to cause anticholinergic side effects (e.g., dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision) and sexual dysfunction (e.g., erectile dysfunction, reduced libido). These side effects make it a less favorable option for someone concerned about sexual function.

questions.text: A girl with known case of BPAD is on lithium therapy. Which statement is incorrect in respect of lithium ?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemodialysis not useful in lithium overdose

options.label: C
options.text: Lithium toxicity can be exacerbated by thiazide

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Hemodialysis not useful in lithium overdose
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Hemodialysis is actually effective in lithium overdose. Lithium is a small ion and is dialyzable, which means that in cases of severe lithium toxicity, hemodialysis can be used to lower lithium levels in the body rapidly and prevent further complications.
  • • Why the other options are correct: B — Lithium can decrease thyroid level:
  • • This is correct. Lithium can lead to hypothyroidism by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. Long-term use of lithium is often associated with a decrease in thyroid function, leading to lower levels of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), especially in patients who are predisposed to thyroid problems.
  • • C — Lithium toxicity can be exacerbated by thiazide:
  • • This is correct. Thiazide diuretics can reduce lithium clearance by the kidneys, leading to higher lithium levels in the body and an increased risk of toxicity. This is an important consideration when managing patients on lithium therapy.
  • • D — Lithium is fetotoxic if given to pregnant female:
  • • This is correct. Lithium is considered fetotoxic and is associated with a risk of congenital malformations, particularly cardiac malformations (e.g., Epstein’s anomaly), if used during pregnancy. It is generally avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy and used with caution under strict medical supervision if absolutely necessary.

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium

options.label: B
options.text: Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium

options.label: C
options.text: Thiazides increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium

options.label: D
options.text: Thiazide promotes GI absorption of lithium

questions.correct_answer: C. Thiazides increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Here's how it works:
  • • Thiazide diuretics reduce the amount of sodium reabsorbed in the kidneys. As a compensatory mechanism, the kidneys may try to retain sodium, which can also result in the reabsorption of lithium, since lithium is reabsorbed in the same manner as sodium in the proximal tubule of the kidney.
  • • This increased reabsorption of lithium can raise the levels of lithium in the blood, leading to toxicity. Symptoms of lithium toxicity include coarse tremors, confusion, and other signs of neurological disturbance.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium:
  • • This is incorrect. Thiazides do not affect the metabolism of lithium. They influence the renal handling of lithium by increasing its reabsorption, not by affecting its metabolism.
  • • B — Thiazides act as an add-on drug to lithium:
  • • This is incorrect. Thiazides may be used for hypertension but can lead to lithium toxicity due to their effect on lithium reabsorption. They do not act as an "add-on" drug that enhances lithium's therapeutic effects; rather, they increase the risk of toxicity.
  • • D — Thiazide promotes GI absorption of lithium:
  • • This is incorrect. Thiazides do not affect the gastrointestinal absorption of lithium. The interaction is primarily renal, where thiazides increase the reabsorption of lithium in the kidneys, not its absorption in the gut.

questions.text: A female patient was on lithium therapy for bipolar disorder for 6 months. She kept the fast for few days due to religious reasons and presented with seizures, coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs. Which of the following should be done to diagnose her condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, meaning the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Factors such as dehydration (which can occur with fasting) or renal dysfunction can lead to increased lithium levels in the blood, resulting in toxicity.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Serum Electrolytes:
  • • While electrolyte disturbances (e.g., sodium imbalance) can affect lithium levels, serum lithium levels are the most direct way to diagnose lithium toxicity.
  • • C — ECG:
  • • ECG can help assess the effects of lithium toxicity on the heart, such as arrhythmias, but it is not the primary diagnostic tool for confirming lithium toxicity. The serum lithium level is the gold standard.
  • • D — MRI:
  • • MRI is not useful for diagnosing lithium toxicity. It may be useful in other conditions (e.g., brain lesions), but in this case, the patient's symptoms point towards a metabolic or drug-induced issue, so serum lithium levels are the most relevant test.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of buspirone is?
questions.explanation:

  • • Buspirone binds to serotonin (5-HT) 1A receptors, which are involved in mood regulation and anxiety. By acting as a partial agonist, it can modulate serotonin activity in a way that reduces anxiety without causing sedation or dependency, which are common with other drugs like benzodiazepines.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: B — 5HT1B antagonism:
  • • Buspirone does not primarily act on 5HT1B receptors. The 5HT1B receptors are involved in serotonin release and vasoconstriction, but they are not the main target of buspirone.
  • • C — 5HT1B partial agonism:
  • • Buspirone does not act as a partial agonist at the 5HT1B receptor. It selectively targets the 5HT1A receptor.
  • • D — 5HT2C antagonism:
  • • Buspirone does not act on 5HT2C receptors. These receptors are involved in various functions including mood and appetite regulation, but buspirone specifically targets 5HT1A receptors.

questions.text: Most effective drug to control tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia in a patient with Parkinsonism is?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Levodopa:
  • • Levodopa is the precursor to dopamine and works by replenishing the dopamine levels in the brain. In Parkinson's disease, dopamine-producing neurons are progressively lost, leading to the hallmark symptoms. Levodopa is converted into dopamine in the brain, effectively helping to control the movement-related symptoms of Parkinsonism, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • • Why the other options are less effective: A — Selegiline:
  • • Selegiline is a MAO-B inhibitor that helps prevent the breakdown of dopamine in the brain. While it can be useful in the early stages of Parkinson’s disease or as an adjunct to levodopa therapy, it is not as effective as levodopa in controlling the major symptoms like tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • • B — Entacapone:
  • • Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor that helps prolong the action of levodopa by preventing its breakdown. While it can enhance the effects of levodopa, it is not the primary drug for controlling Parkinson’s symptoms but rather an adjunct to levodopa.
  • • D — Haloperidol:
  • • Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication, and while it can be used to treat psychosis in patients with Parkinson's disease, it is contraindicated in Parkinsonism because it can worsen motor symptoms, including tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

questions.text: A Patient presented with severe headache associated with photophobia and phonophobia. Which of the following drug can provide immediate relief to this patient?
questions.explanation:

  • • Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that works by constricting blood vessels in the brain and reducing the release of inflammatory substances. This helps in alleviating the pain and associated symptoms of a migraine attack.
  • • Why the other options are less suitable for immediate relief: A — Propranolol:
  • • Propranolol is a beta-blocker often used for migraine prophylaxis (prevention), not for immediate relief of an acute migraine attack. It is effective for long-term management but does not provide fast relief from an ongoing headache.
  • • C — Topiramate:
  • • Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that is also used for migraine prophylaxis (prevention), but it is not typically used for immediate relief of an acute migraine episode.
  • • D — Flunarizine:
  • • Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker used in some cases for migraine prevention, but like propranolol and topiramate, it is not effective for immediate relief of a migraine attack.

questions.text: Which one of the following antidepressant acts by inhibiting the reuptake of both 5HT & NE?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Fluoxetine:
  • • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It primarily inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5HT) alone and does not affect norepinephrine reuptake.
  • • B — Phenelzine:
  • • Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), which works by inhibiting the enzyme monoamine oxidase that breaks down serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine. While it increases the levels of these neurotransmitters, it does not work by inhibiting their reuptake like venlafaxine does.
  • • D — Amitriptyline:
  • • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). It inhibits the reuptake of both serotonin (5HT) and norepinephrine (NE), but it also has many other effects, including anticholinergic, antihistaminergic, and antiadrenergic properties. Although it affects both serotonin and norepinephrine, venlafaxine is a more specific and potent reuptake inhibitor for these two neurotransmitters.

questions.text: A drug addict patient was presented with agitation and ulceration in the skin. This patient had severe itching and scratch marks on the body. On examination he had tachycardia, hypertension and mydriasis. Which one of the following substance responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Agitation and ulceration in the skin (possibly due to repeated scratching or cocaine-induced irritation)
  • • Severe itching and scratch marks (cocaine can cause pruritus as part of the stimulant effects)
  • • Tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis (cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate, high blood pressure, and dilated pupils)
  • • Cocaine is a stimulant that increases the release of norepinephrine and dopamine, leading to these cardiovascular and neurological effects.
  • • Why the other options are incorrect: A — Heroin: Heroin is an opioid, and its effects include sedation, euphoria, constricted pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and hypotension, which are the opposite of what is described in this case.
  • • B — LSD: LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen, and while it can cause agitation, visual distortions, and euphoria, it does not typically cause the pronounced tachycardia, hypertension, or mydriasis associated with stimulant use like cocaine.
  • • C — Cannabinoid: Cannabis or cannabinoids can cause euphoria, dry mouth, and red eyes, but they do not usually produce the tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, and skin ulceration seen in this case. In fact, cannabinoids often cause tachycardia but not the severity seen in stimulants like cocaine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist?

  • • D — Octreotide A somatostatin analog, used to suppress growth hormone secretion in acromegaly, but it is not a GH receptor antagonist. It inhibits GH release from the pituitary, whereas pegvisomant blocks GH action at the receptor level.

questions.text: A female with ovarian cancer was on cisplatin therapy. He presented to hospital with several episodes of vomiting. After giving an antiemetic drug, the patient developed dystonia. The anti-emetic drug most likely to be responsible for these features is

questions.text: A patient suffering for rectal carcinoma and on chemotherapy drugs develops severe profuse diarrhoea. Which of the following drug can begiven to control this diarrhoea

questions.text: Drugs used for chemo induced nausea and vomiting?
